newsitem.title: USA: NHL-LEMIEUX MOVES UP ALL-TIME GOALS LIST IN PITTSBURGH WIN.
newsitem.headline: NHL-LEMIEUX MOVES UP ALL-TIME GOALS LIST IN PITTSBURGH WIN.

text.p: Mario Lemieux moved up the NHL all-time goal scoring list and helped his team move up in the race for playoff positions in leading his Pittsburgh Penguins to a 4-3 victory over the Florida Panthers on Monday.
Lemieux and Jaromir Jagr each had a goal and an assist as the Pengins scored the game's first three goals and held on for a narrow victory.

Lemieux's powerplay goal with 90 seconds left in the second period gave Pittsburgh a 4-2 lead, but it turned out to be the game winner after Rob Neidermayer scored for Florida at 7:36 of the third to make it a one-goal game.
The goal was the 47th of the season for Lemieux and number 610 of his brilliant career, moving him into a tie with the great Bobby Hull for sixth place on the all-time list.

Ian Moran and Josef Beranek also scored and Ron Francis added two assists for Pittsburgh, which moved into a fifth-place tie with the idle New York Rangers in the Eastern Conference, five points behind fourth-place Florida.
Ken Wregget made 26 saves to help the Penguins close in on a post-season position that would give them home ice advantage in the first round of the playoffs.

"That was a gratifying win, we got off to a good start," Pittsburgh coach Craig Patrick said. "I don't think you ever have an easy game against Florida, they work so hard and when they get down I don't know how they can work harder."

Jagr's 46th goal at 3:04 of the second period made it 3-0. But Scott Mellanby scored two minutes later for Florida on a powerplay and Ed Jovanovski closed the Panthers within one before Lemieux gave the Penguins a bit of breathing room.
"I thought we played great in the second and third period, we dominated them," Florida coach Doug MacLean said. "It was frustrating at the end."
John Vanbiesbrouck stopped 28 shots for Florida and picked up an assist on Mellanby's goal.
In Edmonton, Arturs Irbe made 17 saves in relief of Roman Turek and the Dallas Stars moved within three points of first-place Colorado in the Western Conference with a 3-1 victory over the Oilers.
Benoit Hogue put Dallas on the scoreboard at 1:43 of the second period and Greg Adams and Guy Charbonneau scored 67 seconds apart in third period for a 3-0 Dallas lead.
Irbe entered the game with 31 seconds left in the first period after Turek twisted his left knee. He surrendered just a short-handed goal to Daniel McGillis at 12:53 of the third period.

Dallas improved to 46-23-6 with 98 points setting a single-season franchise record. The Stars are also one win shy of the franchise record for seven consecutive victories set 17 years ago when the club was the Minnesota North Stars.
